TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.TRANSL: Sapulungan was up in heaven.

S.FORM: qau vaik a kina kama sema vavua.
qao vaik a kina kama sema vavoa.
S.TRANSL: His mother and father went to the fields.
He was at home.

S.FORM: qau malap tua tjukutjuku, sa tjukutjukutjuku katua salasaladj.
qao malap toa tjokotjoko, sa tjokotjokotjoko katoa salasaladj.
S.TRANSL: He took his ball (or wheel), and played with it with his companions.
Well it got lost.

S.FORM: "qai ła qalian, aki pasainu a ku tjukutjuku a maulaw?"
"qai lja qalian, aki pasaino a ko tjokotjoko a maolaw?"
S.TRANSL: “Hi, friends, where has my ball gone that I’ve lost?”
He looked and looked for it.

S.FORM: manu makelu a maka zua itua buabuang a sema teku.
mano makelo a maka zoa itoa boaboang a sema teko.
S.TRANSL: Well it had fallen down below through a little hole.

S.FORM: vaik timadju a kitjavilił maka zua pinakazuan nua tjukutjuku nimadju a sema tjariteku.
vaik timadjo a kitjavililj maka zoa pinakazoan noa tjokotjoko nimadjo a sema tjariteko.
S.TRANSL: He followed the ball by the way it had gone to the world below.

S.FORM: qau kivadaq timadju tua taqałaqałan: "pasainu a ku tjukutjuku?
qao kivadaq timadjo toa taqaljaqaljan: "pasaino a ko tjokotjoko?
S.TRANSL: He asked the people: “Where has my ball gone?

S.FORM: inika mun a patsun a mapułat?"
inika mon a pacon a mapoljat?"
S.TRANSL: Haven’t any of you seen it?”
“We don’t know.

S.FORM: pai sa-u kivadaqu ti vuvu i Ḍaḍengeraw."
pai sa-o kivadaqo ti vovo i Dradrengeraw."
S.TRANSL: Go and ask granny Ḍaḍengeraw.”
He went to ask her.
She said: “I don’t know.”

S.FORM: manu patsunan ni Sapulungan izua i tjaiteku i surur.
mano paconan ni Sapolongan izoa i tjaiteko i soror.
S.TRANSL: Then Sapulungan saw it there under the bed-platform.
Sapulungan picked it up.
“Here’s my ball, granny.”

S.FORM: "ini anga ka ken a tsemged a patsun."
"ini anga ka ken a cemged a pacon."
S.TRANSL: “I can’t see clearly any more.”
“I’m going to stay with you, granny.”
“Others are going fishing, granny.
What am I to take?”
“Take this pot-holder to fish with.”
Well the others didn’t catch anything;
but he used a pole to carry the fish he caught.
“Granny, others are going hunting.
What am I to take?”

S.FORM: "katsuu aitsu a ku velayan a qemałup."
"kacoo aico a ko velayan a qemaljop."
S.TRANSL: “Take this net-needle to hunt with.”
Off he went.
But the others said: “Don’t go near this chap.
It’s taboo to carry a net-needle when we’re hunting.”
They went hunting;

S.FORM: manu malap ti Sapulungan a semuliaw.
mano malap ti Sapolongan a semoliaw.
S.TRANSL: and Sapulungan caught lots,
but the others didn’t catch anything.
“Granny, others are going head-hunting.
What am I to take?”
“Take my net-needle.”
“Don’t come near us.

S.FORM: namasi velayan sun," ayain nua qaliqali.
namasi velayan son," ayain noa qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: You’re carrying a net-needle,” said the others.
But he killed a lot,
while the others didn’t kill anybody.
They were all angry.
“What are we going to do with this chap?
Why haven’t we been able to do anything?
Let’s kill him.”

S.FORM: qau kivala ti Sapulungan; kilangda tua mazepzepzep.
qao kivala ti Sapolongan; kilangda toa mazepzepzep.
S.TRANSL: Sapulungan was out for a stroll, and heard them discussing.
So he was going to be killed.
He went indoors

S.FORM: pasemalaw tua vuvu: "uzau ru qetsin aken nua taqałaqałan.
pasemalaw toa vovo: "ozao ro qecin aken noa taqaljaqaljan.
S.TRANSL: and told the granny: “The people are planning to kill me.

S.FORM: uri vaik aken, vuvu, a sema tjarivavaw."
ori vaik aken, vovo, a sema tjarivavaw."
S.TRANSL: I’m going off to heaven, granny.”
“No, Sapulungan, stay on here.
What does it matter what others say?”

S.FORM: "ini, vuvu, uri vaik aken a sema tjarivavaw."
"ini, vovo, ori vaik aken a sema tjarivavaw."
S.TRANSL: “No, granny, I’m going to heaven.”
He planted a small whetstone in the ground.
It grew big enough to reach up to heaven.
He took his ball.

S.FORM: "aitsu, vuvu, nu metad sa ku inapuan, sataladju anga tua surur."
"aico, vovo, no metad sa ko inapoan, sataladjo anga toa soror."
S.TRANSL: “Now, granny, when my betel-nut quid has dried, put it under the bed-platform.”

S.FORM: vaik ti Sapulungan a sema vavaw, a tsemikel a sema tjarivavaw.
vaik ti Sapolongan a sema vavaw, a cemikel a sema tjarivavaw.
S.TRANSL: Sapulungan went up and returned to heaven.

S.FORM: ka zemuker i tjarivavaw, djakadjaken nimadju a ventseluq.
ka zemoker i tjarivavaw, djakadjaken nimadjo a venceloq.
S.TRANSL: When he reached heaven, he kicked and broke the whetstone pillar (implied);

S.FORM: manu matsay anga mapułat a taqałaqałan i Valivaliw.
mano macay anga mapoljat a taqaljaqaljan i Valivaliw.
S.TRANSL: and all the people of Valivaliw were killed.

S.FORM: amin anga ti Ḍaḍengeraw nu vałut.
amin anga ti Dradrengeraw no valjot.
S.TRANSL: Only Ḍaḍengeraw survived.

S.FORM: ka i tjarivavaw anga ti Sapulungan, manu "pasainu sun?
ka i tjarivavaw anga ti Sapolongan, mano "pasaino son?
S.TRANSL: When Sapulungan got to heaven, his parents asked: “Where have you been?
We thought you must be dead.
But here you are.”
“I followed (my ball) to the world below.

S.FORM: qau izuanga ken i tjai vuvu i Ḍaḍengeraw.
qao izoanga ken i tjai vovo i Dradrengeraw.
S.TRANSL: And I stayed there with granny Ḍaḍengeraw.

S.FORM: qau uri qetsin aken; mana ku sivaik a sema maza i tjarivavaw," aya timadju a pasemalaw tua matjałałak.
qao ori qecin aken; mana ko sivaik a sema maza i tjarivavaw," aya timadjo a pasemalaw toa matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: But I was going to be killed; that’s why I left and came back here to heaven,” he told his parents.

S.FORM: qemaung anga a kina kama, saka "kana matsay sun, kana inika men a kemłang," aya tiamadju.
qemaong anga a kina kama, saka "kana macay son, kana inika men a kemljang," aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: His mother and father cried. They said; “If you had died, we wouldn’t have known.”

S.FORM: azua i Valivaliw a mui mana natałiw ni Sapulungan.
azoa i Valivaliw a moi mana nataljiw ni Sapolongan.
S.TRANSL: The white stone at Valivaliw is from Sapulungan’s whetstone.
amin
